bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: wounds and injuries of the spine
gunshot injuries of the lumbar vertebræ
gunshot fractures of the apophyses of the lumbar spine
bullet into the abdominal cavity through spinal canal

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding
case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE.—Corporal John E——, Co. M, 14th New York Heavy Artillery, being wounded in front of Petersburg, on July 30, 1864, was sent to Washington, and admitted to Douglas Hospital on August 3d, with peritonitis and complete paraplegia. He died on the same day. The autopsy revealed the passage of the bullet into the abdominal cavity through the spinal canal, and laceration of the liver. The pathological specimen was contributed to the Army Medical Museum by Assistant Surgeon W. Thomson, U. S. A. It is figured in the adjoining wood-cut (FIG. 196).

figure.head: FIG. 196.—Two lumbar vertebræ fractured vertically. Spec. 3583, Setct Sect . I, A. M. M.
